title: How many seats in the Legislative Yuan will the Kuomintang party win in the next Taiwan parliamentary elections?
preds: After Honk King engagement with mainland China has lost popularity. Kuomingtang represents that.

The economic condition in Taiwan is at its best, anti China sentiment in Hong Kong, trade war and uncertainty in global stage. People opt for status quo and distance themselves from
China. Pro China kuo min tang is too close to China which pushes the voters towards DPP. President tsai liberal stance got lots of support from young voters but her progressive acts might push older voters towards kmt but businesses might lean towards dpp as they benefited from trade war btw China and the US

I've been influenced by the forecast of @Shenqishui99 and the update from @V-Y- to further reduce KMT seats.
I'll share the space with @petequinn. :-)

With 2 days to go the mood is still anti China.  Though HK situation remains the same, China’s standoff with Indonesia around Natuna islands is bad news for KMT who want better relationships International news is also picking up Taiwan elections and sounding bad omens for KMT. Itself potentially driving self fulfilling prophesy

How many seats in the Legislative Yuan will the Kuomintang party win in the next Taiwan parliamentary elections?
Hattip to @V-Y- and @sebawi for thier insights which reduced my enthusism for KMT seats.

- The DPP now holds 68 out of 113 seats, while the KMT has 35 seats. 
- Opposition party likely to' grow because of disaffection-ed ruling party voters)
- Undecided voters - presumably inclined to KMT - may be lured to 3rd Parties

Looking at the news, it seems less and less plausible that the KMT will gain more than 42 seats, while it seems more and more plausible that they may repeat their devastating result from the last election. However, a lot depends on the undecided voters that are mostly regarded as KMT-friendly but have not decided upon their choice [1]. PFP may step in the breach. I'll take the risk of under- and overestimating KMT's performance by allocating low two digits values to x < 36 and the 43 < x < 49 bracket. If nothing happens in the last days before the election, this will be my final forecast. [1] https://focustaiwan.tw/politics/201912310018
I was reading recent polls incorrectly.
Based on current opinion polls and how that has translated into seats, using the first past the post system

How many seats in the Legislative Yuan will the Kuomintang party win in the next Taiwan parliamentary elections?
Hattip to @cafebedouin for cogent analysis and to @sebawi for an execellent overview. More parties = fewer seats.

In contrast to the presidential race, the results of the parliamentary elections are affected by a number of additional factors. In the legislative election, there are other considerations at work than in the presidential election [4]. Latest developments and information require me to adjust the foreast: first, there are the latest - and final - polls [1], second, the support of PFP candidates by Foxconn founder Terry Gou [2], third, the relevance of the party lists in this election [3] and, fourth, the large margin of undecided voters [7]. Most of the pundits assume that the KMT won't repeat its result from 2016 (35 seats). My forecasts are strongly influenced by their opinion which may be dangerous. I still haven't found a proper foundation to compare the polls for the last and the current election. While it is a comparison of apples and pears using [1] and [6], the current state of the polls indicate that the KMT will indeed gain some seats. However, the composition of the party lists seems to have been a crucial factor for the decline in KMT support in the last months - and I hadn't taken them into consideration so far. In addition, Gou's support for the PFP may worsen the KMT's prospect due to the fact that both parties attract a similar voter base. Personal scandals of the KMT presidential candidate may reduce the trust of voters even further [5]. On the other hand, Han asked his followers to stop answering correctly to pollsters [8]. Thus, the large amount of undecided voters may also be a consequence of voters declining to respond honestly. In consequence, I've reduced the probability of the KMT receiving less than 36 seats and receiving between 50 and 56 seats in favor of the options in-between. I'm less and less convinced that the KMT can gain more than 50 seats and I'm confident that they won't get less than 36 seats. At the moment, I'm divided on the 36 < x < 42 and the 43 < x < 49 brackets. I'll make up my mind adjusting those two brackets in the coming days. [1] http://focustaiwan.tw/news/aipl/201912310018.aspx
[2] https://www.taiwannews.com.tw/en/news/3848739
[3] https://thediplomat.com/2019/12/taiwans-usually-obscure-party-lists-might-swing-its-legislative-election/
[4] https://frozengarlic.wordpress.com/2019/12/11/the-state-of-the-polls-2019-vs-2015/
[5] https://www.taiwannews.com.tw/en/news/3848787
[6] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Taiwanese_legislative_election#Opinion_polling
[7] https://www.taiwannews.com.tw/en/news/3847132
[8] https://frozengarlic.wordpress.com/2019/12/10/is-han-succeeding-in-ruining-polls/
Will make gains without getting a majority

More parties, fewer undecided. Most likely result is election will push % into the low 30s, which will edge up the number of seats a bit higher than last round. But, they probably need to get +35% to get more than 42, which seems pretty unlikely. --------------DPP-----KMT---------
=======================

They are currently polling at ~ 24 to 33% (depending on the poll), which translates to about 27 to 37 seats (if popular vote were to equal number of seats, which is NEVER the case...). My first guess is based on simple / simplistic / simpleton's logic from those polls, and nothing else.

Though Taiwan actually has a mixed system of first-past-the-post presidential and district candidate elections and proportional representation (PR) party votes, I will just assume for simplicity's sake that opinion polling on the legislative election roughly reflects what the outcome will be.   Although the KMT’s presidential candidate is currently far behind in the polls (see my posts in the GJP question about the presidential election [1,2]), the KMT is still in a pretty strong position to win a majority of more than 56 seats in the Legislative Yuan. At the very least, the KMT is all but certain to increase its seat number from where it currently stands at 35. The current make-up of the Yuan was the result of a drubbing for the KMT in 2016 - support for the KMT was "at an all-time low after the anti-KMT 2014 Sunflower Movement. Even KMT supporters were jaded with the party when it swapped presidential candidates months before the election, from the wildly unpopular Hung Hsiu-chu to the slightly less unpopular Eric Chu" [3]. I think it's very unlikely that, despite recent scandals, the KMT will lose more seats than it currently has. I am taking the average of recent polling since news broke out five days ago that a Chinese spy in Australia has defected and revealed Beijing's extensive meddling in the Taiwanese 2020 general election, primarily on behalf of the KMT [4]. This seems like it is having a large impact on the 2020 election races [5], which is why I am only considering the most recent polling. Unfortunately, there have only been two recent polls - the average of the two shows a lead of ~2.6% for the DPP [6] (note that most polling prior to this shows a lead for the KMT). But it also shows that ~29.9% of voters are undecided, which means that there is still a lot of room for movement.  I will update as new polling comes out. [5] https://www.scmp.com/news/china/politics/article/3039468/taiwan-president-tsai-ing-wen-looks-boost-claims-chinese-spy

*changed probabilities from 49% to 47% (>36) and from 47% to 49% (36<x<42)

Taking into consideration that the results of the last election (DPP: 68 seats; KMT: 35 seats) were largely influenced by extraordinary factors (Sunflower Movement, Swap of KMT Candidate), it is not heretic to assume that they are able to gain more seats in the 2020 polls. However, there are some factors that blur this positive prospect for the KMT [1, 2]: 1) Alleged election meddling by China in support of the KMT
2) The ongoing conflict in Hong Kong
3) The participation of the TPP as new third-party force besides the NPP (while it is not unlikely that these two parties in the end compete for the same seats with each other according to [2], voters that reject the firm attitude  of the DPP and the NPP(?) against China but are unsatisfied with the KMT may see an option here) Current polls show a lead for the DPP (33%) over the KMT (24%), the TPP (10,4%) and the NPP (8,7%) [3]. I wasn't able to find a source to compare these opinion polls with those conducted four years ago for the 2016 election but the race seems to be closer than the opinion polls on the presidential election indicate. After hong kong situation people in taiwan will vite against this oartty .

KMT & TPP parties will play an important roll in dictating how many seats the DPP wins. KMT 's support isn't as low as it was previously and TPP is a wild card (although pro-China leanings will certainly play a major part in hindering their success). I give the DPP a good shot at gaining some ground but not a lot. I'd be surprised to see them gain more than 10 seats max.
Kmt Will do better than the polls show now due to Chinese influence
Analysis of current predictions and election system
Considering past election results and recent Kuomingtanfg's campaign, it seems that they won't be able to exceed the last election results, i.e., 35 seats.

The increasingly polarized politics of the region will foment more anti-Communist sentiment especially in a state such as Taiwan, but much depends on Chinese actions in Hong Kong between now and the year's end.

With the situation in Hong Kong persisting, Taiwanese voters will, either consciously or unconsciously, feel an urge to express their anti-Communism.  In the last few elections, the party has lost seats and this trend is due to change so the party will build upon 35 seats.
